ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot of spanish grammar and vocab.

This class improved my handle on the language particularly in spoken fluency and additional grammar concepts. The cultural insights gained though cultural comparison and analysis were also very interesting.
My speaking skills improved lots, as well as my general confidence in speaking Spanish. It was interesting to learn about Spanish culture, and read the play at the end of the course.
I have a much better grasp of Spanish tenses, as well as an expanded vocabulary.

I developed my grammar skills through lessons and frequent practice. The class was held primarily in Spanish, so I became a lot more comfortable with speaking the language and thinking in Spanish. LinguaMeeting sessions and the final cultural project also provided opportunities to explore the cultures of various different Spanish-speaking countries.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I found the projects to be low-stress and engaging.

The structure is very conducive to improvement in the language. The homework reinforces the class content and vice versa. Additionally, there are many fun/collaborative projects and activities that make the course more effective.

Strengths are the Professor Sabe, as well as the organization of the course. Everything was really transparent with clear deadlines and homework. She was really accommodating the wide range of levels within the class.

The Spanish sequence is a doozy, much like all language courses at Yale. Having a class four/five days a week is challenging. On the one hand, I think the homework and class time are helpful for language learning. On the other hand, as this is required for graduation, it is a huge burden on the student. 

This class in particular was honestly not too bad, I think the professor was great. The exams and compositions were also good. 

One weakness was the sheer amount of work required every day. Some days, between class and homework, I would have to choose between falling behind in all my other courses or completing a Spanish assignment, reaching this point after already spending hours working on things. It is a good course, but it was almost prohibitively stressful to keep up with at times.
Strengths: frequent practice, independent and group work, and a conversational atmosphere. Weaknesses: grading sometimes inconsistent with time taken to complete assignments

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Depends. The course is a fairly large time commitment if you have no previous exposure or an already full schedule.

Absolutely, especially with Lourdes Sab. She is an absolutely amazing professor who is clearly passionate about the subject. Beyond class content, she's also super nice, and it's clear she cares about her students. Additionally, her feedback is very good, resulting in even faster progress.
I would recommend this course to others if you plan on doing Spanish, but it is also a higher workload than most languages. However, it was very useful and engaging.
I would recommend it if you are completing your language requirement or just want to get better at Spanish.

I would recommend this course to other students that have preparation in Spanish and wish to expand their speaking abilities. The course covers a lot of material, so at times it could feel fast if one does not have a proper foundation.
